How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.

A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is e

A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be casual about relations

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of poten

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential par

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Pa

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be nore interchangea

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase 'there are

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.

It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase 'there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as wel

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase 'there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well

A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little

 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.

Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification,

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details popsted b

Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it

Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well

It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.

A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the rpersonal details even r

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real loife, maybe 15% of t

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real loife, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the app

Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real loife, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90 per

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"

Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"". And that is not a g

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"". And that is not a good thing.
I think dating apps are a mixed bag.
 If used wi

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"". And that is not a good thing.
I think dating apps are a mixed bag.
 If used with cautin and a hgea

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"". And that is not a good thing.
I think dating apps are a mixed bag.
 If used with cautin and a hgealthy sketicism, the

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"". And that is not a good thing.
I think dating apps are a mixed bag.
 If used with cautin and a hgealthy sketicism, they deifintely improv

Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"". And that is not a good thing.
I think dating apps are a mixed bag.
 If used with cautin and a hgealthy sketicism, they deifintely improve the chance of a sol

I think dating apps are a mixed bag.
 If used with caution and a healthy skepticism, they definitely improve the chance of a solid match. But i

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"". And that is not a good thing.
I think dating apps are a mixed bag.
 If used with caution and a healthy skepticism, they definitely improve the chance of a solid match. But if

Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"". And that is not a good thing.
I think dating apps are a mixed bag.
 If used with caution and a healthy skepticism, they definitely improve the chance of a solid match. But if used frivilously,

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has made dating and relationships better. In the past, in order to meet the "right person" you have to be almost preternaturally lucky. A chance invitation, lucky coincidence and happenstance ruled the day. For every million compatible partners you'd be lucky to meet one. Now, with the advent of dating apps and social media, you can find compatible people in your area with a few clicks.

And there's no rule you can't go out of your area. I have met people who have travelled thousands of miles to meet someone they thought might be the right one.
Technology has also made it easier to communicate.


But this ease of communication comes with a cost.
It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable too. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"". And that is not a good thing.
I think dating apps are a mixed bag.
 If used with caution and a healthy skepticism, they definitely improve the chance of a solid match. But if used frivilously, they can be an entree into a world of pain

It's easy to send a message, but it's hard to know if the other person is interested.
 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has become more true than ever!
Technology has also made it easier to cheat., as well
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in he last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate. In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"". And that is not a good thing.
I think dating apps are a mixed bag.
 If used with caution and a healthy skepticism, they definitely improve the chance of a solid match. But used frivolously, they can be an entrée into a world of pain and miscommunication.

 It's easier to lie. It is easier to be too casual about relationships. In the feed of potential partner after potential partner, faces can become a blur. Partners can be more interchangeable. The phrase "there are more fish in the sea" has never been more true.
Technology has also made it easier to cheat.
 There is precious little independent verification, in most dating apps, of the personal details and photos posted by members. Is the photo accurate? Was it taken in the last year? Is it even a photo of the person who posted it? Are the personal details even remotely accurate? In real life, maybe 15% of the people you meet are fit and trim. On the apps, its well night 90% if not more!
Technology has also made it easier to be a "player"". And that is not a good thing.
I think dating apps are a mixed bag.
 If used with caution and a healthy skepticism, they definitely improve the chance of a solid match. But used frivolously, they can be an entrée into a world of pain and miscommunication.
